name: Mini Mike's Metro Minis
tagline: A city-themed collection of over 400 cute models you can remix or use outright in your own works
body:
### Screenshots

![](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/B3ovngLCUAA8HcZ.png)
![](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/B2n3JUBCEAAMrlV.png)
![](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/B2x5xdmIEAAP6fw.png)
![](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/B224TU-CEAAMwBg.png)
![](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/B4EbEpcCIAE1NZf.png)
![](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/B351eynCQAA3jRx.png)
![](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/B8LVrGlIgAA6UAn.png)
![](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/B8LVrMRIQAA6nr1.png)
![](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/B8LVqXhIQAELJwS.png)
![](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/B8LVq9gIMAAo9TJ.png)

### Formats included

**/vox** is the original .vox files, created in MagicaVoxel.  This is compatible with all sorts of voxel software like VoxelShop, Qubicle 2, etc.

**/collada** and **/fbx** are optimized polygon files for use in 3d software packages like Cinema4d, 3D Studio, Maya, or for game frameworks like Unity3d or Unreal Engine.

**/unity-plugin** contains all the models already setup for Unity3D with box colliders, wheel colliders on the vehicles and so on. Getting 400+ models ready for use in your game can be a chore, look how nice it is to have it all done for you!

### Parts

* 91 characters
* 37 vehicles
* 14 trees/planters
* 35 residential buildings
* 42 commercial buildings
* ...and another 200+ props and models for filling out the city

### Licensing

These models are licensed under Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International,
which allows you to do pretty much whatever you want, commercial or not, provided
you give appropriate credit, a link to the license and indicate if changes were made.
(Read the details.)

For attribution, all you need to do is: in the credits of your project, say 
something like Additional Artwork by Mike Judge, and if you're feeling kind, 
please send a link to your project to him on twitter so he can brag about it!

### Authors and Contributors

The artist behind this project was Mike Judge (@mikelovesrobots). You can find him on
[Twitter](http://twitter.com/mikelovesrobots). If you'd like him to do similar art for your
game, he's open for contract work. The MMMM collection took just under 100 consecutive days.
